awd_titl_txt: CNS Core: Small: Event Identification in Evaluation of Internet Outages
awd_abstract_narration:
The EIEIO (Event Identification and Evaluation of Internet Outages) project will develop new algorithms to (1) improve coverage of Internet outage detection to cover millions of Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) (the primary current Internet) networks that are today uncovered, and extending coverage to Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6) (the new protocol used by about 30% of America today).  (2) analyze this raw data to determine identifiable outage events.  (3) relate these events to real-world causes using other datasets.  The results of this work will be additional information about Internet reliability, allowing citizens to make informed choices of provider, governments to assess the services their citizens receive, and ISPs to evaluate their offerings and justify improvements.  Data from this work will help society understand the impact of natural disasters (such as hurricanes) as they are occurring and will be made available to researchers at no cost.

Understanding Internet reliability is critically important to us. Recent methods have emerged that directly measure Internet-wide reliability, but the EIEIO (Event Identification and Evaluation of Internet Outages) project proposes three steps to move our understanding forward: (1) Improving  IPv4 coverage to include millions of networks that cannot be reliably measured today, and extending outage detection to IPv6;  (2) converting the millions of raw observations into identifiable events; (3) relating these events to real-world causes.

The intellectual merit of the EIEIO project is to fundamentally expand Internet outage detection in these three ways.  The EIEIO project will develop new algorithms to increase IPv4 coverage with more sensitive analysis, examine passive and active measurements that reach to IPv6.  The EIEIO project will develop clustering algorithms that group raw data to events at Internet scales (millions of events over months of data). The EIEIO project will improve confidence in these results with careful comparison of outage observations and events from multiple data sources, including different observation methods and external data sources.

The EIEIO project will help increase confidence in our ability to use fine-grain observations of Internet outages for IPv4 and IPv6 and provide data that will help network architects change network designs to improve network resilience.  Results from the project could help citizens selecting network providers to make informed choices about their network purchases, governments to assess the service their citizens receive, and ISPs compare their offerings and justify improvements. Network outage data can assist first responders and citizens to understand natural disasters (such as hurricanes) as they are occurring. This project will also quantify network reliability to assist policy makers evaluating telecommunications policy and economics, and to carry out long-range planning.  Finally, this data will motivate improvements by ISPs to Internet reliability, improving the Internet for all users.  Data generated from this project will be made available to researchers at no cost and used to support education and research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The Event Identification and Evaluation of Internet Outages (EIEIO) project developed new algorithms to help understand Internet reliability by improving coverage of Internet outage detection, identifying events in this raw data, and relating these events to the real world.

Our research goals are to expand Internet outage detection in these several:

•             developing new algorithms to help understand Internet reliability by improving coverage of Internet outage detection,

•             developing algorithms that cover IPv4 and IPv6,

•             identifying events in this raw data and relating these events to the real world.

We accomplished all of these goals:

1a. The EIEIO project developed new algorithms to examined how ISP assign users to public IPs, and how these policies interact with outage detection. We track ISP-wide address use, showing some ISPs use more IPs during the day, and showing how to filter out this and other ISP operational behaviors from actual network outages. This work was peer-reviewed and presented in the a paper “Ebb and Flow: Implications of ISP Address Dynamics” at accepted to the Passive and Active Measurements Conference for 2024.

1b. Data from the EIEIO project contributed to new algorithms to detect changes in human activity. (this goal was also supported by the MINCEQ project, NSF #2028279). Following Covid-19, we discovered we could see Work-From-Home behavior in some networks where IP addresses become active each day, but that trend suddenly stops. This work was peer-reviewed and presented in the paper “Inferring Changes in Daily Human Activity from Internet Response” at ACM IMC 2023.

2.          The EIEIO project made significant progress on the problem of using passive data sources to detect outages in IPv6. Our insight is that analysis of passive data sources scales with IPv6 addresses that are used, avoiding a need to understand the vast, unused portions of IPv6. This work was presented in a poster at IMC 2022, and a technical paper is currently under peer review.

3a. The EIEIO project evaluated the role of partial Internet outages, defining the terms “peninsulas” and “islands” Our work is some of the first to define and quantify partial network connectivity with Internet-wide measurements. A technical paper on this work is currently under peer review.

3b. Building on EIEIO work on partial Internet outages, summer undergraduate research Tarang Saluja used these ideas to improve the sensitivity RIPE DNSMon, a popular tool to evaluate the DNS Root. Saluja found that three-quarters of reported IPv6 outages are either measurement errors due to islands (Atlas VPs that claim to route IPv6 but cannot reach the public IPv6 Internet) or peninsulas (routing problems in the core Internet that operators should address). This work used data from EIEIO but was supported by a separate REU grant (NSF grant 2051101, PI: Jelena Mirkovich).

3c. Erica Stutz carried out a measurement-based comparison of our streaming and batch-processed Internet outage systems to quantify the “cost” of near-real-time results in streaming outage detection. This work currently in a technical paper that will be submitted shortly for peer review. Stutz’ work began as part of an ISI Summer REU (NSF grant 2051101, PI: Jelena Mirkovich) and continued with an REU extension added to EIEIO.

EIEIO shared a great deal of data with external researchers: Over the course of the EIEIO project (from 2020 to 2024) the project released 1212 datasets to 169 researchers.

The broader impact of the EIEIO was to provide data help network architects and ISPs to change heir design to improve reliablity. The project also made this data available on the public web at https://outage.ant.isi.edu. This website is being used by at least one federal agency to understand U.S. network outages, particularly in times of natural disaster.

 


Last Modified: 03/04/2025
Modified by: John S Heidemann

Our research goals are to expand Internet outage detection in these several:

We accomplished all of these goals:


1a. The EIEIO project developed new algorithms to examined how ISP assign users to public IPs, and how these policies interact with outage detection. We track ISP-wide address use, showing some ISPs use more IPs during the day, and showing how to filter out this and other ISP operational behaviors from actual network outages. This work was peer-reviewed and presented in the a paper Ebb and Flow: Implications of ISP Address Dynamics at accepted to the Passive and Active Measurements Conference for 2024.

Our insight is that analysis of passive data sources scales with IPv6 addresses that are used, avoiding a need to understand the vast, unused portions of IPv6. This work was presented in a poster at IMC 2022, and a technical paper is currently under peer review.


3a. The EIEIO project evaluated the role of partial Internet outages, defining the terms peninsulas and islands Our work is some of the first to define and quantify partial network connectivity with Internet-wide measurements. A technical paper on this work is currently under peer review.

The project also made this data available on the public web at https://outage.ant.isi.edu. This website is being used by at least one federal agency to understand U.S. network outages, particularly in times of natural disaster.
